text: this is AO scott in New York City the
end of September means many things one
thing it means is the New York Film
Festival and the opening night film is
the much-anticipated sort of film of the
moment which is David Fincher's the
social network written by aaron sorkin
which is about or kind of about or to
some extent about Mark Zuckerberg the
the one of the founders of facebook the
social media that everybody loves to use
all the time and that will start things
off and then there's there's quite a
range of stuff to follow there are three
films this year from Romania Aurora from
Christy poo you who made the death of
mr. Laza rescue a very nice new film by
Raju Muntean called the Tuesday after
Christmas look at a marriage that's on
the brink of falling apart and a lot of
other interesting and diverse stuff to
from all over the world including this
year's surprising and somewhat
controversial winner of the top prize at
the Cannes Film Festival uncle boonmee
who can recall his past lives it's a
movie from Thailand very abstract very
dreamy but very beautiful another one is
an italian film called Lacroix Travolta
which is basically told in three parts
the first part is about an old man the
second part is about a goat and it's in
goat without subtitles and the third
part is about a tree and I found maybe a
little dull or dry or strange but it's
it's actually one of the funniest and
most moving and profound films that I've
seen them this year there's also a
French film of gods and men
a very moving somber drama about a
monastery in in algeria where french
monks are living during the Civil War of
the 1990s and trying to to survive and
to figure out how to be good decent
people how to live up to their to their
vows in the midst of a very chaotic and
violent situation New York Film Festival
is always a very exciting time based on
what I've seen which is about half of
the program so far this year is looking
pretty good and you'll probably be
hearing more about it from my colleagues
as the event unfolds meanwhile this is
AO scott for the new york times
